hypothesis_content.title: Liquidity Gap Mean Reversion After Stress Events
hypothesis_content.statement: Following a market stress event (liquidity crash), when BTC's 1-hour bid-ask spread exceeds 2.5x its 30-day median, entering a long position on spread normalization yields positive risk-adjusted returns within 48 hours.
hypothesis_content.rationale: Market makers withdraw during stress, creating temporary liquidity gaps. As volatility subsides, market makers return, compressing spreads and providing mean reversion opportunities. The October liquidity crash created structural memory of such events.
entry_conditions: Market regime transitions from STRESS to NEUTRAL within last 6 hours
BTC price volatility (1h) drops below 1.5% after spike >3%
Cumulative order book depth (top 5 levels) increases by >15% from stress low

exit_conditions.take_profit: Spread returns to within 1.2x of 30-day median OR 4% price appreciation
exit_conditions.stop_loss: Spread widens further to >3x median OR 2% price decline

hypothesis_content.falsification_criteria: Spread normalization fails to correlate with price appreciation in >40% of post-stress events, or spreads remain elevated >72 hours despite regime shift.
